key_insight: eMOSAIC combines multimodal molecular and protein information with per‑prediction out‑of‑distribution (OOD) aware uncertainty estimates to produce more reliable binding affinity predictions across multiple targets, improving trust in polypharmacology predictions.
problem_solved: Reduces unreliable affinity predictions and poor generalization in polypharmacology by detecting OOD inputs and providing individual uncertainty scores so practitioners can identify low‑confidence predictions before costly experiments.
method: Fuse multimodal representations of compounds and targets (e.g., molecular graphs, sequences/structural features, experimental covariates) into a joint prediction model.
Produce individual uncertainty estimates and OOD flags for each prediction to calibrate confidence and selectively downweight or flag risky predictions.
Evaluate on cross‑target/polypharmacology benchmarks to show improved calibration, robustness, and actionable accuracy compared to baselines.
impact: Provides ML practitioners a practical framework for safer, more interpretable affinity prediction in drug discovery, enabling better decision making and reduced experimental waste by flagging low‑confidence, OOD predictions.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: multimodal inputs (compound, protein, metadata) → eMOSAIC model → affinity + uncertainty + OOD flag
Calibration plot: predicted vs observed affinities showing improved calibration with uncertainty
Comparison chart: performance and error bars for baseline vs eMOSAIC across multiple targets (polypharmacology)
Icon set: molecule + protein with confidence badges (high/low) to visualize per‑prediction trust
paper_title: Multimodal out-of-distribution individual uncertainty quantification enhances binding affinity prediction for polypharmacology
paper_authors: Amitesh Badkul, Li Xie, Shuo Zhang, Lei Xie
